title: Does the CIA use anything similar to Novichok, a hard to detect toxic nerve agent commonly used to assassinate by Russian agents? - Quora

response.answer_text: That is something that you would more likely find in an Army lab—like the weaponized anthrax that was used to kill and terrorize Americans before the Iraq invasion. It is interesting to note that Novichok-like compounds (Novichok is not really just ONE nerve agent) are stored and studied at Porton Down, near where the alleged Novichok poisoning cases took place.

Novichok, the “newbie" is not difficult to detect. It causes a slow death, that is going to lead anyone sickened by it to consult a doctor. The symptoms are pretty specific, dying being one of them. There are a myriad of chemical compounds that can kill, and are difficult or impossible to reverse. I reckon the Company has employed more than one.

Novichok was used by the U.S. military in the 1950s, whether synthesized or produced I dont know but several former Soviet republics have synthesized it. It was not used by Russians to kill people in Salisbury if thats what you are talking about. Thats just more plotting by Britiain and the U.S. to blame Russia. It is easy to make Russia sinister and remind people of the Soviet period. "Everyone" would be dead if Russia led Novichok attack, victim told
